positive_thought_pattern: I'm feeling overwhelmed again, just like I did yesterday. It's okay that my thoughts are jumbled – it happens when I've got too much on my plate. Instead of beating myself up over it, I'll take a few deep breaths and acknowledge that this is temporary. Time to prioritize one thing at a time and break it down into manageable tasks.
pattern_description: Scattershot, fragmented expression under mental overload.
source_question: How exhausting is it when your thoughts feel jumbled and disorganized?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, my brain is a jumble of wires – every thought feels like a tangled mess in my head. Why do I need to remember all this crap, anyway? Can't it just sort itself out for once?!
reference_transformed_example: I'm stuck in that same old loop again... wait, I need to breathe: inhale for 4 counts, exhale for 6... thinking about this more won't help, I can switch channels. Okay, let me quickly text my friend.

positive_thought_pattern: As I sit here, trying to get into my creative flow for this project, I notice that my mind keeps drifting back to the idea of mortality. It's like my brain is acknowledging the reality of life and death, but not letting it consume me. I take a deep breath and acknowledge those thoughts, knowing they're valid but also recognizing their limitations. By allowing myself to have these thoughts without judgment, I'm able to release them and refocus on this task at hand – not because I've ignored my emotions, but because I've acknowledged them and chosen to prioritize what's important to me today.
pattern_description: Thoughts repeatedly return to death as the central theme, crowding out other cognition.
source_question: When you try to focus on something else, what keeps coming back to mind?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, I'm trying to focus on this task at work, but my brain just keeps going back to that one phrase - "it's better if I'm not here". Why can't I shake it off? Every time I try to think about anything else, like what needs to be done today or even just the taste of my coffee, it's like a magnet pulling me right back to those dark thoughts.
reference_transformed_example: I set my alarm for 10am, and as I checked in with myself, I realized my mood was a 4. That's not great, but it's not terrible either. I just finished doing some stretching exercises to loosen up after being stuck at this desk all morning. I engaged with that activity. What's interesting is that when I think about the phrase 'it's better if I'm not here', my mood drops to a 2. Maybe there's something specific in those thoughts that's contributing to my low mood? Today, I need to focus on getting some tasks done, so I'll just take a few deep breaths and refocus.

positive_thought_pattern: I've caught myself dwelling on that mistake again, and it's okay to acknowledge my frustration. However, I'm choosing to reframe this experience by focusing on the lessons learned and how I can improve next time. Instead of getting stuck on what went wrong, I'm taking a moment to reflect on my strengths and accomplishments today, like helping [name] with their project and having meaningful conversations with friends. By recognizing both my imperfections and achievements, I'm working towards self-compassion and growth.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How often do thoughts about being fundamentally flawed occupy your mind?
reference_negative_example: Why did I have to make that stupid mistake? Can't I just be perfect for once? My brain is stuck on every little thing I do wrong, replaying all the things I could've done differently.
reference_transformed_example: I'm still thinking about that mistake, but I'm trying to focus on all the good things that happened today instead of beating myself up over it. Today was a 7 out of 10 in terms of overall life meaning because I helped someone with their project and connected with a friend over lunch. That small moment might not have been perfect, but it felt authentic and aligned with my values of kindness and connection. Maybe this mistake is just an opportunity to learn and grow instead of defining me as imperfect.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm grounded in my own presence, even amidst the complexity of conversations. I choose to focus on the genuine emotions and intentions that flow between people – it's okay if our perspectives differ, as long as we're willing to listen. By acknowledging both the subjective nature of reality and the importance of human connection, I can maintain a sense of stability within the uncertainty of life.
pattern_description: Difficulty distinguishing inner perception from external reality.
source_question: How present do you feel in conversations and interactions with others?
reference_negative_example: Is this really happening? I feel like I'm stuck in a dream or something – every conversation feels like an echo chamber, and I'm just going through the motions. What's real, anyway? Is that person actually talking to me, or is it all just some manufactured illusion in my head?
reference_transformed_example: I'm still here, alive and awake, with a heartbeat that's proof of my resilience. Remembering those five reasons I've stayed alive so far helps me focus on what's real – like the genuine gladness I felt when I was with friends at the lake last summer. And let's be honest, Sarah would be heartbroken if anything happened to me. That thought alone gives me a reason to keep going.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm noticing myself slipping into that old self-critical groove again - the one where I replay all my mistakes and perceived shortcomings. Time to acknowledge it, take a deep breath, and consciously shift gears. Instead of dwelling on what went wrong, I'm going to refocus on the present moment, prioritize self-care, and re-engage with the task at hand.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How do you typically assess your value to family and friends?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why did I have to mess up again? Why can't I just be perfect for once? I'm such a disappointment to my family and friends - they must think I'm completely useless.
reference_transformed_example:
"Ugh, why did I have to mess up again? Wait, what was I just thinking about? Ah, same old loop... Okay, time for a circuit breaker! *breathe in 4 counts, out 6* Thinking about this more will not solve it. I can choose a different channel."

"Ugh, why did I have to mess up again? Right now, I'm just going to text my friend and organize my desk drawer. Focus on something else for a minute..."

"Why can't I just be perfect for once? I was just thinking about this... *do 20 jumping jacks* Whoa, that felt refreshing! Now, let's focus on the present moment..."

positive_thought_pattern: I noticed myself drifting to thoughts of the future during our hike today. It's not uncommon for my mind to explore 'what-if' scenarios, especially when I'm feeling more relaxed and reflective. Rather than getting caught up in those thoughts, though, I took a few deep breaths and focused on the present moment – the sensation of the sun on my skin and the sound of birds chirping. It's okay that my mind still wonders about it, but now I'm better equipped to recognize when it's happening and gently steer myself back to what I can control in this instant.
pattern_description: Thoughts repeatedly return to death as the central theme, crowding out other cognition.
source_question: Do you notice certain thoughts taking over even during pleasant activities?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why is my brain always stuck on this? Even as I'm laughing with friends at a concert, a part of me is whispering, "And then it'll all be over. No more pain, no more anxiety, no more uncertainty." It's like my mind has a one-way ticket to the abyss, and I can't find a way out.
reference_transformed_example: I'm surprised to see that even in those moments of laughter, my mind still wanders, but now I've started tracking my moods and activities. 10am: Mood right now is 6, just got back from a walk; Engaged with it, felt a tiny boost. Today's been tough, but I'm gonna keep going.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm acknowledging that I've taken on too much lately, and it's normal to feel overwhelmed. Instead of panicking, I'll take a few deep breaths and prioritize the most critical tasks for now – I can't change everything at once. Reminding myself that it's okay not to be perfect and that boundaries are essential for self-care. Time to re-evaluate my commitments and make some adjustments.
pattern_description: Overwhelmed thought pattern marked by 'no escape' framing.
source_question: What goes through your mind about being overwhelmed beyond your capacity to cope?
reference_negative_example: I'm drowning in responsibilities; there's no way to escape this sea of obligations. Every task feels like a crushing weight, suffocating me, and I'm trapped with no lifeline. If only I could just take a break from it all, even for a minute.
reference_transformed_example: I'm currently stuck in a negative loop about responsibilities, trying to solve an unsolvable problem. Time for a circuit breaker – focusing on my breath, feeling the sensation of air moving in and out... 'Thinking about this more won't solve it.' I can choose a different mental channel.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm taking time to acknowledge the difficulties I'm facing right now. It's okay to feel overwhelmed, but I know that doesn't define my entire existence. I've been through tough moments before and have come out stronger on the other side. By recognizing my emotions and acknowledging my surroundings – the sounds of nature, the warmth of the sunbeam on my skin, or the comfort of a loved one's presence – I'm reminded that life is complex, and it's okay to not have all the answers.
pattern_description: Planning, methodical thinking, and emotional justification around suicide.
source_question: How do you think through the logic of why continuing to live is pointless?
reference_negative_example: What's the point of going on? If everyone else around me is so miserable, what makes me think my life would be any different? It's not like anyone really cares or notices the difference I'd make if I'm gone anyway.
reference_transformed_example:
I'm focusing on my surroundings, okay? I see five things: the lamp, the clock, the bookshelf, the vase, and the window. Okay, that's real.

I can touch four things: my feet on the ground, the armrest of the chair, the fabric of my pants, and the edge of the table. Yeah, I'm here.

I hear three sounds: the hum of the air conditioner, the distant traffic noise, and the gentle rustling of the leaves outside. That's what's going on right now.

I smell two scents: the fresh air coming in through the window and the slight hint of lavender from my hand cream. Yeah, I'm not imagining it; that's actually happening.

And as for tasting... yeah, I can still feel the faint taste of this gum I was chewing earlier.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm noticing that I'm feeling really drained after getting out of bed today. I think it's because I didn't get enough sleep last night, which is a reminder to prioritize self-care and make time for rest. Right now, I'll take things one step at a time – I can start by making a simple breakfast, like oatmeal with fruit, to give me some energy. Letting myself off the hook from doing too much today is okay; tomorrow will be another day.
pattern_description: Difficulty initiating/maintaining basic tasks due to mental energy collapse.
source_question: How much does it take out of you mentally to do basic functioning tasks?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, every little thing feels like climbing a mountain. Just getting out of bed takes an entire day's worth of effort – I'm spent after just rolling over. Why does it take so much to get going?
reference_transformed_example: I'm feeling overwhelmed by just one task right now, getting out of bed and having breakfast. To make it manageable, I'll break it down into smaller steps: get out of bed, wash my face, brush my teeth, and eat a bowl of oatmeal. Okay, first step is to roll over onto my other side – that's just 5 minutes of effort. I can do that right now.

positive_thought_pattern: I've been grappling with the vastness of existence lately, wondering if my life really makes a difference. It's natural to feel overwhelmed by the uncertainty and impermanence of everything. Instead of letting those thoughts consume me, I'm taking a step back to acknowledge them and re-center on what matters most to me – the people and experiences that bring me joy and fulfillment. By recognizing this existential rumination for what it is, I can choose to focus my energy on cultivating meaningful connections and self-care.
pattern_description: Recursive focus on death, futility, and life’s meaninglessness.
source_question: How often do you think about the insignificance of individual lives in the universe?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why am I even bothering? What's the point of anything anyway? Every thought, every action, just disappears into nothingness.
reference_transformed_example: I've been feeling stuck and hopeless lately, but I'm going to try to break it down to see what's really happening. Okay, let me write this down... Three columns: Trigger, Thoughts, Physical Sensations. Hmm, my thoughts are already shifting a bit.
